@inproceedings{wangRevisiting2024,
  title = {Revisiting and Improving Scoring Fusion for
       Spoofing-aware Speaker Verification Using Compositional
       Data Analysis},
  booktitle = {Proc. {{Interspeech}}},

      Noé, Paul-Gauthier and Yamagishi, Junichi},

Revisiting and Improving Scoring Fusion for Spoofing-aware Speaker Verification Using Compositional Data Analysis

Abstract

Fusing outputs from automatic speaker verification (ASV) and spoofing countermeasure (CM) is expected to make an integrated system robust to zero-effort imposters and synthesized spoofing attacks. Many score-level fusion methods have been proposed, but many remain heuristic. This paper revisits score-level fusion using tools from decision theory and presents three main findings. First, fusion by summing the ASV and CM scores can be interpreted on the basis of compositional data analysis, and score calibration before fusion is essential. Second, the interpretation leads to an improved fusion method that linearly combines the log-likelihood ratios of ASV and CM. However, as the third finding reveals, this linear combination is inferior to a non-linear one in making optimal decisions. The outcomes of these findings, namely, the score calibration before fusion, improved linear fusion, and better non-linear fusion, were found to be effective on the SASV challenge database.

keywords:
speaker verification, anti-spoofing, fusion, log-likelihood ratio, ternary classification

1 Introduction

Automatic speaker verification (ASV) systems are vulnerable to spoofed synthetic speech data that clone the target speakers’ voices [1]. By combining ASV and spoofing countermeasure (CM), which ideally should reject any spoofed data, we expect to be able to construct a spoofing-aware ASV (SASV) system that only accepts speech data from real (bona fide) humans who match the target speaker’s identity.

An SASV system can be a cascade of ASV and CM sub-systems [2]. The ASV and CM make separate binary decisions, and the input is accepted if it is accepted by both sub-systems. Another design used by many SASV systems is to produce one score and make one binary decision. Let the input be 𝒙=(𝒙(p),𝒙(r))∈𝒳𝒙superscript𝒙𝑝superscript𝒙𝑟𝒳\bm{x}=(\bm{x}^{(p)},\bm{x}^{(r)})\in\mathcal{X}bold_italic_x = ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_X, where 𝒙(p)superscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝒙(r)superscript𝒙𝑟\bm{x}^{(r)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the probe (test) and reference (enrollment) samples, respectively, and can be waveforms, features, etc. An SASV system defines a scoring function g:𝒳→ℝ:𝑔→𝒳ℝg:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_g : caligraphic_X → blackboard_R that maps 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}bold_italic_x into a score ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT surpasses a threshold, the system takes the action of 𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝\mathtt{accept}typewriter_accept, claiming that 𝒙psubscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}_{p}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bona fide and matches the speaker identity in 𝒙rsubscript𝒙𝑟\bm{x}_{r}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Otherwise, it takes the action of 𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝\mathtt{reject}typewriter_reject.

This paper focuses on the SASV systems that produce ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using score-level fusion. The idea is to use ASV and CM sub-systems to obtain an ASV score sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and CM score scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then use a score-level fusion function h:ℝ×ℝ→ℝ:ℎ→ℝℝℝh:\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_h : blackboard_R × blackboard_R → blackboard_R to merge the scores into ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that there are feature-level fusion and end-to-end methods [3, 4, 5], which do not need to produce {sasv,scm}subscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. We argue that score-level fusion is useful because {sasv,scm}subscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } provides invaluable extra explanations on the model decision. Some evaluation metrics, such as tandem equal error rate (t-EER) [6], also require separated sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

An example SASV system using score-level fusion (baseline B1 of the SASV challenge [5]) is illustrated in Fig. 1. Its ASV sub-system extracts embeddings from 𝒙(p)superscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝒙(r)superscript𝒙𝑟\bm{x}^{(r)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and computes their cosine similarity as sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which indicates the degree that 𝒙(p)superscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝒙(r)superscript𝒙𝑟\bm{x}^{(r)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT match in terms of speaker identity. The CM sub-system extracts an embedding from 𝒙(p)superscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and produces a score scm∈ℝsubscript𝑠cmℝs_{\text{cm}}\in\mathbb{R}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R using a neural network. A higher scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates that 𝒙(p)superscript𝒙𝑝\bm{x}^{(p)}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is more likely to be bona fide. Hence, it is intuitively reasonable to fuse the scores by ssasv=sasv+scmsubscript𝑠sasvsubscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{sasv}}=s_{\text{asv}}+s_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

More advanced fusion functions have been proposed in the SASV and other biometrics fields [7, 2]. Although most are intuitively reasonable, for example, normalizing the numeric range of sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT before summation [5], the link between practice and theory is not always clear. Therefore, the implicit assumptions, link to optimal decisions, and room for improvement remain elusive.

Starting from the summation of the ASV and CM scores, we scrutinize the score fusion using tools from decision theory. After reformulating SASV as a classification task that involves three data classes but requires a binary decision, we interpret SASV scoring from the perspective of compositional data analysis and show that the summation of sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a reasonable choice if the ASV and CM scores are proper log-likelihood ratios (LLRs). Hence, the interpretation indicates that score calibration before fusion is beneficial. The interpretation also leads to an improved fusion method that uses probabilistic models to compute LLRs for summation. Finally, the summation-based fusion is analyzed from the perspective of optimal decision policy and found to be theoretically inferior to a non-linear fusion method.

The above interpretations of SASV have not been presented as far as the authors are aware. They differ from one existing study that treats {sasv,scm}subscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } as posterior probabilities [8]. Experiments were conducted on the SASV challenge database [5]. The calibration before fusion was found to be effective, especially for linear fusion by summation. The linear and non-linear fusion of LLRs outperformed baselines, and the latter outperformed the systems fusing posterior probabilities [8]. The results are reproducible. 111Code site: https://github.com/nii-yamagishilab/SpeechSPC-mini.

2 Interpreting and improving SASV score fusion

2.1 SASV is not fusion of congruent binary classifiers

By definition, an SASV system should only 𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝\mathtt{accept}typewriter_accept if the input is uttered by the bona fide target speaker; otherwise, 𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝\mathtt{reject}typewriter_reject. Fusing ASV and CM scores for a binary decision in the SASV system seems to be similar to the score fusion in multi-modal biometric verification [9, 10].

Let 𝐗={𝒙,1⋯,𝒙}K\bm{\mathrm{X}}{}=\{\bm{x}{}_{1},\cdots,\bm{x}{}_{K}\}bold_X = { bold_italic_x start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT 1 end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , bold_italic_x start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT } be the inputs to a biometric verification system with K𝐾Kitalic_K modalities (e.g., speech and face). The system determines whether inputs match the claimed identity (H𝗍𝖺𝗋{H}{}_{\mathsf{tar}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT) or not (H𝗇𝗈𝗇{H}{}_{\mathsf{non}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT). Assuming that 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘\bm{x}_{k}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are statistically independent, we can use the Bayes’ formula [11] to obtain

Assuming that the LLRs and priors are equal to the ground truth, our decision strategy for minimizing the decision error rate is to accept 𝗍𝖺𝗋𝗍𝖺𝗋{\mathsf{tar}{}}sansserif_tar if and only if ∑k=1K𝗅𝗅𝗋𝗇𝗈𝗇𝗍𝖺𝗋⁢(𝒙k)+log⁡π𝗍𝖺𝗋1−π𝗍𝖺𝗋>0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝗅𝗅𝗋𝗍𝖺𝗋𝗇𝗈𝗇subscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝜋𝗍𝖺𝗋1subscript𝜋𝗍𝖺𝗋0\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathsf{llr}^{\mathsf{tar}{}}_{\mathsf{non}{}}(\bm{x}_{k})+\log% \frac{\pi_{\mathsf{tar}{}}}{1-\pi_{\mathsf{tar}{}}}>0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_llr start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG > 0 [11]. The sum of LLRs is the weight of evidence to favor 𝗍𝖺𝗋𝗍𝖺𝗋\mathsf{tar}{}sansserif_tar, which is known as independent additivity of LLRs [12].

We may hastily treat SASV as biometric verification with two modalities, namely, ASV and CM. Thus, fusion by scm+sasvsubscript𝑠cmsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{cm}}+s_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be interpreted as the sum of LLRs, given that the scores approximate the LLRs. With four hypotheses involved, independent additivity of LLRs and Eq. (1) no longer hold [12, sec.4.3].

2.2 Interpreting SASV using compositional data analysis

A better starting point is to have three exhaustive and mutually exclusive hypotheses [2, 13]: the input probe is bona fide and matches the reference (H𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿{H}{}_{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT), bona fide and unmatched (H𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿{H}{}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT), or spoofed (H𝗌𝗉𝖿{H}{}_{\mathsf{spf}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT). 222It is unnecessary to separate H𝗌𝗉𝖿{H}{}_{\mathsf{spf}{}}italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT into matched and non-matched cases since both should be rejected [6]. To interpret this classification task with three classes but two actions {𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝,𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝}𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝\{\mathtt{accept},\mathtt{reject}\}{ typewriter_accept , typewriter_reject }, we use compositional data analysis [14, 15].

Because ∑iπi=∑iPi=1subscript𝑖subscript𝜋𝑖subscript𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖1\sum_{i}\pi_{i}=\sum_{i}P_{i}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, where i𝑖iitalic_i is the index of the vector’s element, 𝝅𝝅\bm{\pi}bold_italic_π and 𝑷𝑷\bm{P}bold_italic_P are compositional vectors on the probability simplex 𝕊3superscript𝕊3\mathbb{S}^{3}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. During testing, we compute p⁢(𝒔;𝜽𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿)𝑝𝒔subscript𝜽formulae-sequence𝗍𝖺𝗋𝖻𝖿p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta}_{\mathsf{tar.bf}}{})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), p⁢(𝒔;𝜽𝗌𝗉𝖿)𝑝𝒔subscript𝜽𝗌𝗉𝖿p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta}_{\mathsf{spf}{}})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and p⁢(𝒔;𝜽𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿)𝑝𝒔subscript𝜽formulae-sequence𝗇𝗈𝗇𝖻𝖿p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of a test sample and plug them into Eq. (6). Since the selected parametric distributions may be different from the actual distribution of 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}bold_italic_s, the estimated LLRs may be inaccurate. Hence, we can optionally apply discriminative calibration on the LLRs before fusion.

2.5 Fusion method 3: nonlinear fusion of LLRs

The interpretation so far leads to the simple form of score fusion in Eqs. (5) and (6). Importantly, however, it also reveals a major limitation for making decisions. Inequality. (7) is a necessary but not sufficient condition to achieve Ineq. (9). For example, a sample with [P(H|𝗌𝗉𝖿𝒙),P(H|𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿𝒙),P(H|𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿𝒙)]=[0.05,0.65,0.3][P({H}{}_{\mathsf{spf}{}}|\bm{x}),P({H}{}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}|\bm{x}),P({H}{}_% {\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}|\bm{x})]=[0.05,0.65,0.3][ italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) ] = [ 0.05 , 0.65 , 0.3 ] will be rejected by Ineq. (9) but falsely accepted by (7). The overall decision cost cannot be lower than that based on the optimal decision policy in Ineq. (9) (or (10)), given that we know the true LLRs and priors.

To support the above argument, we generated ASV and CM scores using Gaussian distributions and a uniform prior, which enables us to compute the true LLRs and compared the linear and non-linear decision boundaries. As Fig. 3 indicates, the non-linear one based on Ineq. (10) leads to a lower decision cost, particularly, a lower false acceptance rate. Note that, Ineqs. (8) and (10) are agnostic to the data distributions, and we use Gaussians in simulation only for convenience.

On the basis of Ineq. (10), we define a new fusion method

ssasv=−log⁡[(1−ρ)⁢e−𝗅𝗅𝗋𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿⁢(𝒔)+ρ⁢e−𝗅𝗅𝗋𝗌𝗉𝖿𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿⁢(𝒔)].subscript𝑠sasv1𝜌superscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝗅𝗅𝗋formulae-sequence𝗍𝖺𝗋𝖻𝖿formulae-sequence𝗇𝗈𝗇𝖻𝖿𝒔𝜌superscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝗅𝗅𝗋formulae-sequence𝗍𝖺𝗋𝖻𝖿𝗌𝗉𝖿𝒔s_{\text{sasv}}=-\log\big{[}(1-\rho)e^{-\mathsf{llr}^{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}_{% \mathsf{non.bf}}(\bm{s})}+\rho e^{-\mathsf{llr}^{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}_{\mathsf{% spf}{}}(\bm{s})}\big{]}.italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - roman_log [ ( 1 - italic_ρ ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - sansserif_llr start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ρ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - sansserif_llr start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (11)

The usage is similar to that in Sec. 2.4, but we plug the LLRs into Eq. (11). Unfortunately, the prior-dependent ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ cannot be decoupled from the LLRs, and it needs to be decided, for example, by grid search on a development set. The green solid line in Fig. 3 shows the decision boundary when ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ is computed from different priors. It performs reasonably well.

As a special case, if each p⁢(𝒔;𝜽)𝑝𝒔𝜽p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ ) is implemented as a Gaussian distribution, Eq. (11) turns out to be equivalent to the so-called Gaussian back-end fusion [21, Eq.(1)]. The link between Gaussian back-end fusion and the optimal decision has not been shown before as far as the authors are aware. Detailed proof is available on the code site (see link on page 1).

3 Experiments

We verified the effectiveness of the three fusion methods on the SASV challenge dataset [5] and the official training, development, and evaluation splits.

3.1 Model recipe and evaluation metrics

All eight experimental systems were based on the open-sourced SASV challenge baseline B1 (Fig. 1) and used the pre-trained ECAPA-TDNN-based ASV [22] and AASIST-based CM [23] embedding extractors, which were provided by the challenge organizers. The differences in the systems are

  • •

    B1 is a replicate of SASV B1. The ASV branch requires no training, and the neural network in the CM branch is trained using binary cross-entropy given scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the labels for CM. The SASV score is computed by ssasv=scm+sasvsubscript𝑠sasvsubscript𝑠cmsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{sasv}}=s_{\text{cm}}+s_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • •

    L2 is similar to B1 but uses Eq. (6) for score fusion. Each p⁢(𝒔;𝜽)𝑝𝒔𝜽p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ ) is a Gaussian with a full covariance matrix.

  • •

    L3 follows L2 but uses Eq. (11) for score fusion.

  • •

    B1c, L2c, and L3c are variants of B1, L2, and L3, respectively, but calibrated scores or LLRs before fusion. The calibration function is f⁢(x)=a⁢x+b𝑓𝑥𝑎𝑥𝑏f(x)=ax+bitalic_f ( italic_x ) = italic_a italic_x + italic_b.

  • •

    B1v2 (B2-v2 in [5]) and Post (PR-S-F in [8]) were included for reference. They interpret scores as posterior probabilities and fuse by ssasv=σ⁢(scm)+sasvsubscript𝑠sasv𝜎subscript𝑠cmsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{sasv}}=\sigma(s_{\text{cm}})+s_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ssasv=σ⁢(scm)×σ⁢(sasv)subscript𝑠sasv𝜎subscript𝑠cm𝜎subscript𝑠asvs_{\text{sasv}}=\sigma(s_{\text{cm}})\times\sigma(s_{\text{asv}})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) × italic_σ ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), respectively [24]. The σ⁢(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot)italic_σ ( ⋅ ) is a sigmoid function.

The parameters 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta}bold_italic_θ, ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, and {a,b}𝑎𝑏\{a,b\}{ italic_a , italic_b } for calibration were tuned on the development set.

All systems have about 82.5 k trainable parameters in the the neural network for CM, which has three hidden layers with 258, 128, and 64 neurons, respectively. All layers used a leaky ReLU activation with a negative slope value of 0.3. All systems were trained on a Tesla V100 card using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 5×10−55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, batch size of 24, and weight decay with a coefficient of 1×10−31superscript1031\times 10^{-3}1 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The maximum number of training epochs was 10, and the checkpoint with the best CM EER on the development set was used for evaluation. The implementation was done using SpeechBrain [25], and the training took less than one day per system.

The SASV-EER [5] was used to gauge the discrimination power of ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The log-likelihood-ratio cost CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr [26] was also computed and decomposed into CllrminsubscriptCllrmin\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{min}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to measure the discrimination and calibration performance of ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The t-EER [6] was computed given {sasv,scm}subscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } or the LLRs. Each system was trained and evaluated for six rounds, where each round used a different seed to randomly initialize the neural network in the CM sub-system. The averaged results are listed in Table 1. The confidence interval of SASV-EER was using the Interspeech official toolkit with the default setting.

3.2 Results

Calibration before fusion was useful: As reported in the original paper [5], B1 achieved an SASV-EER of around 20%. As Fig. 4(a) shows, due to the large difference in the dynamic ranges of ASV and CM scores, the latter dominated the fused SASV score. The values of CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr and CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were higher than 1 bit, indicating that the SASV scores were not useful for making decisions. By calibrating sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT before fusion, B1c reduced the SASV EER to 2.73%, and CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr-based metrics also improved. From Fig. 4(b), we can observe that the distribution of sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT was ‘stretched out’, and the fused ssasvsubscript𝑠sasvs_{\text{sasv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT sasv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT better separated the three classes of data.

When fusing LLRs, the system pairs {L2, L2c} and {L3, L3c} showed that the gain of the calibration was diminishing. This is understandable because the dynamic range of ASV and CM scores are handled by the covariance matrix of p⁢(𝒔;𝜽)𝑝𝒔𝜽p(\bm{s};\bm{\theta})italic_p ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_θ ). However, calibrating before fusion was still helpful, especially in the case of linear fusion in Eq. (6). Compared with L2, L2c’s EER was reduced to 1.56%, and its CllrCllr\mathrm{Cllr}roman_Cllr was only 0.14 bits.

Non-linear fusion of LLRs was better: Rather than fusing the ASV and CM scores, L2, L3, and their variants fused the estimated LLRs. The nonlinear fusion of LLRs in L3c led to the best SASV-EER in our experiments. The difference between L3c and L2c was small, possibly because the test data set of the SASV challenge can be well separated using a linear decision boundary in the space of LLRs, as Fig. 4(c) and (d) show.

Compared with B1v2 and Post, which treat the ASV and CM scores as posterior probabilities, L2c, L3, and L3c performed similarly or better in terms of SASV-EER, and their CllrcalibsubscriptCllrcalib\mathrm{Cllr}_{\text{calib}}roman_Cllr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT calib end_POSTSUBSCRIPTs were much lower. The results suggest that the fusion methods based on compositional data analysis are also practically useful.

Finally, the t-EER measures the discrimination power of {sasv,scm}subscript𝑠asvsubscript𝑠cm\{s_{\text{asv}},s_{\text{cm}}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } or LLRs and is agnostic to their calibration and fusion. Hence, the t-EERs of B1 and B1c are the same. Similarly, the four systems fusing LLRs have the same t-EER. It was observed that using the LLRs led to a lower t-EER than raw or sigmoid-transformed sasvsubscript𝑠asvs_{\text{asv}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT asv end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and scmsubscript𝑠cms_{\text{cm}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT cm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is evidence to encourage the sub-systems to produce LLRs.

4 Conclusions

This paper presented an alternative interpretation of SASV score fusion based on compositional data analysis. We suggested practices and improved fusion methods that may have been ignored or used ad hoc. First, the calibration of scores or LLRs before fusion was found to be helpful, especially when linearly fusing raw scores or LLRs. Second, rather than fusing raw scores, estimating and fusing LLRs turned out to be better in experiments. Third, the linear fusion of LLRs was found to be inferior to the non-linear one in both analysis and experiments. What is presented in this paper is by no means the only way to interpret SASV fusion, thus is expected to foster other studies.

A.1.2 Decision cost and optimal decision policy

To minimize the overall risk, the Bayes decision rule tells us to select the action with a smaller conditional risk [11]. Accordingly, the decision policy is

a={𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝,if ⁢R⁢(𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝|𝒙)>R⁢(𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝|𝒙)𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝,if ⁢R⁢(𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝|𝒙)≤R⁢(𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝|𝒙).𝑎cases𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝if 𝑅conditional𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝒙𝑅conditional𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝒙otherwise𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝if 𝑅conditional𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝒙𝑅conditional𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝒙otherwise{a}=\begin{cases}\mathtt{accept},\quad\text{if }R(\mathtt{reject}|\bm{x})>R(% \mathtt{accept}|\bm{x})\\ \mathtt{reject},\quad\text{if }R(\mathtt{reject}|\bm{x})\leq R(\mathtt{accept}% |\bm{x})\\ \end{cases}.italic_a = { start_ROW start_CELL typewriter_accept , if italic_R ( typewriter_reject | bold_italic_x ) > italic_R ( typewriter_accept | bold_italic_x ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL typewriter_reject , if italic_R ( typewriter_reject | bold_italic_x ) ≤ italic_R ( typewriter_accept | bold_italic_x ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW . (15)

In other words, the optimal decision policy for an SASV system is to 𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝\mathtt{accept}typewriter_accept the input probe if the conditional risk R⁢(𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝|𝒙)𝑅conditional𝚊𝚌𝚌𝚎𝚙𝚝𝒙R(\mathtt{accept}|\bm{x})italic_R ( typewriter_accept | bold_italic_x ) is smaller than R⁢(𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝|𝒙)𝑅conditional𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝒙R(\mathtt{reject}|\bm{x})italic_R ( typewriter_reject | bold_italic_x ). Otherwise, the system should 𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝𝚛𝚎𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝\mathtt{reject}typewriter_reject the input.

This is the optimal decision policy for ASV as a typical binary classification task [27, (2.33)].

Note that the LLRs are on the left hand side, while the priors (and decision costs) are on the right hand side. Because the LLRs are decoupled from the priors, the system can be designed to produce the LLRs without considering the priors. It is the user, who deploys the system into an application, assign the decision costs, asserted priors, and accordingly the decision threshold. The decoupled LLRs and priors are preferred in a forensic context [28, 27]. A similar decision policy can be derived when ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1italic_ρ = 1, i.e., CM without ASV.

Unfortunately, when ρ∈(0,1)𝜌01\rho\in(0,1)italic_ρ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), the LLRs and priors cannot be decoupled. The ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ is needed to compute the score, and the SASV system designer has to estimate the value of the ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ, for example, on the basis of the statistics from the development data. In our experiment, ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ was found through grid search by minimizing the decision risks on the development data.

A.2 Optimal decision policy when decision costs are equal

For an actual application, we need to assign values to the decision costs on the basis of the application’s requirements. For example, the cost for missing a sample of 𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿formulae-sequence𝗍𝖺𝗋𝖻𝖿\mathsf{tar.bf}{}sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf may be high for a smart-speech device since the user may be annoyed if their voice is falsely rejected. However, the costs for falsely accepting 𝗌𝗉𝖿𝗌𝗉𝖿\mathsf{spf}{}sansserif_spf and 𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿formulae-sequence𝗇𝗈𝗇𝖻𝖿\mathsf{non.bf}{}sansserif_non . sansserif_bf may be high for online banking. False acceptance of imposters may lead to disastrous financial loss.

Following the common assumptions in other studies (e.g., [21]), we now consider a particular case in which Cfa𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿=Cfa𝗌𝗉𝖿=Cmiss𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿superscriptsubscript𝐶faformulae-sequence𝗇𝗈𝗇𝖻𝖿superscriptsubscript𝐶fa𝗌𝗉𝖿superscriptsubscript𝐶missformulae-sequence𝗍𝖺𝗋𝖻𝖿C_{\text{fa}}^{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}{}=C_{\text{fa}}^{\mathsf{spf}{}}{}=C_{\text{% miss}}^{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}{}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fa end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fa end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT miss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A.2.1 Link to Gaussian fusion back-end

Note that the Gaussian fusion back-end parameterizes each likelihood function using a Gaussian distribution, but any other parametric distribution can be used.

A.2.2 Link to the sub-optimal decision policy

In Sec. 2.5, we showed that the linear fusion of LLRs is linked to the decision policy in Ineqs. (7) and (8). For convenience, we write Ineqs. (7) again below

It has been described that any vector of posterior probabilities 𝑷=[P(H|𝗌𝗉𝖿𝒙),P(H|𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿𝒙),P(H|𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿𝒙)]⊤\bm{P}=[P({H}{}_{\mathsf{spf}{}}|\bm{x}),P({H}{}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}|\bm{x}),P% ({H}{}_{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}|\bm{x})]^{\top}bold_italic_P = [ italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) , italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies Ineq. (28) also satisfies Ineq. (32), but the reverse is not always true. In other words, Ineq. (32) is a necessary but not sufficient condition to achieve Ineq. (28).

Ineq. (32) is necessary to achieve Ineq. (28): Note that P(H|𝗍𝖺𝗋.𝖻𝖿𝒙)+P(H|𝗇𝗈𝗇.𝖻𝖿𝒙)+P(H|𝗌𝗉𝖿𝒙)=1P({H}{}_{\mathsf{tar.bf}{}}|\bm{x})+P({H}{}_{\mathsf{non.bf}{}}|\bm{x})+P({H}{% }_{\mathsf{spf}{}}|\bm{x})=1italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_tar . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) + italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_non . sansserif_bf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) + italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT sansserif_spf end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) = 1. A.3 Comparing with ternary classification

In Sec.A.1, we defined SASV as a classification task with two actions but three data classes. We may compare it with a ternary classification task. For convenience, let the three classes be 𝒴={H,1H,2H}3\mathcal{Y}=\{{H}{}_{1},{H}{}_{2},{H}{}_{3}\}caligraphic_Y = { italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT 1 end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT , italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT 2 end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT , italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT 3 end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT }. The three possible actions are to assign the input to one of the three classes.

A.3.2 Maximizing the decision utility

In contrast to minimizing the decision cost, we may conduct a Bayesian decision by maximizing the utility [20]. Let us define a utility function U⁢(a,y)𝑈𝑎𝑦U(a,y)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_y ) that returns the utility (or reward) when the system the action a𝑎aitalic_a while the ground-truth label is y𝑦yitalic_y. A generic value table of U⁢(a,y)𝑈𝑎𝑦U(a,y)italic_U ( italic_a , italic_y ) for a ternary classification task is shown in Table 5. ∑iUi⁢1P(H|i𝒙)>∑iUi⁢2P(H|i𝒙)\sum_{i}U_{i1}P({H}{}_{i}|\bm{x})>\sum_{i}U_{i2}P({H}{}_{i}|\bm{x})∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) > ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) (43)

and

∑iUi⁢1P(H|i𝒙)>∑iUi⁢3P(H|i𝒙).\sum_{i}U_{i1}P({H}{}_{i}|\bm{x})>\sum_{i}U_{i3}P({H}{}_{i}|\bm{x}).∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) > ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_H start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x ) . In [15, sec.10.3], Ineq. (47) and its relationship with compositional data analysis is discussed. Inequality. (47) is different from Ineq. (28): the former is derived when maximizing the decision utility given a scalar utility matrix.

A.4 On spoofed sample

A spoofed sample should be rejected by SASV regardless of whether it sounds like the target speaker. If the spoofed probe is forged by an attacker (i.e., biometric imposters in ISO/IEC 30107), it is supposed to sound like the target speaker’s voice; however, the algorithm to create the spoofed probe may not be good enough to mimic the voice. Hence, the spoofed sample should be rejected regardless of its similarity to the target speaker’s voice.

Suppose the ‘spoofed’ sample is created by an authentic user who wants to make it less similar to their own voice (i.e., biometric concealers). In that case, this application is considered more relevant to voice anonymization [29] rather than SASV. Of course, an SASV system should also reject the ‘spoofed’ sample since it intended use is to conceal the speaker’s identity.
